_prev_prog_2.Description: This process includes two interconnected tanks available for isopentane drain down. Sniffers are utilized to detect potential leaks and a deluge system is installed for emergency response.

CERTIFICATION

Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10 the information submitted in this RMP is to the best of the signer?s knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, true, accurate and complete.  This certification is intended to comply with the 40 CFR 68.185 requirements.



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Raft River Energy 1?s Cassia County, Idaho, facility is a geothermal power production facility. The Raft River Facility uses 183,000 pounds of the flammable gas isopentane in the heat exchange/electrical generation process.  Isopentane is stored at the facility in excess of the 10,000 pound threshold quantity defined in 40 CFR 68.130. The facility has been identified as meeting the regulatory criteria requiring submittal of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  The objective of the RMP is to prevent the accidental release of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and/or the environment from short-term (acute) exposure and to mitigate the severity of a release that may occur.  



Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Section 68.12 requires a facility with extremely hazardous toxic and flammable substances used in its process in an amount exceeding a threshold quantity to develop and implement a RMP.  A process is defined in 40 CFR 68.3 as ?any activity involving a regulated substance including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or on-site move

ment of such substances, or combination of these activities?.



Based on the criteria defining the three program levels, the facility was identified as Program Level 2.  There is one public receptor within the endpoint based on a worst-case release scenario, which was determined to be .47 miles. The Raft River Facility does not use or store regulated toxic substances therefore toxic release scenarios have not been prepared. Flammable substance (isopentane) release scenarios have been evaluated. The nearest endpoint receptor is a temporary residence for two individuals located .47 miles from the facility. The radius of impact from the worst case scenario is .5 miles.



The facility maintains instruments and equipment to detect potential isopentane leakage and maintains emergency response equipment to remediate potential releases and reduce the potential for fire or explosion. Staff are trained to recognize and respond to potential releases utilizing computer automated control systems.  



This is a new facility with no five-year accident history. All accidents will be documented and investigated in accordance with the plan. Investigations will include an evaluation of the cause of the release and response protocols for the purpose of improving the physical responses and emergency systems that are implemented. 



At the end of each major RMP heading section, a table correlating with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP*Submit requirements has been included.  These tables include the most current information regarding the Facility.  This RMP must be periodically updated when changes occur to the process, or when a new process is added which meets the definition requiring an RMP.



Table 1 provides a matrix of the regulatory citation, the corresponding RMP element and the section of the RMP in which the regulatory requirement is advertised.





OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS 

The offsite consequence analysis is comprised of two elements: (1) worst-case rel

ease scenario; and (2) alternative release scenario.  These elements are calculated through air dispersion modeling using the required parameters listed in 40 CFR Section 68.22.



The EPA RMP guidance documents states that data must be submitted on:



1. Worst-case release scenario analysis of covered processes as follows: 

Report one worst-case release scenario for each Program 1 process. Program 1 processes must have no public receptors within the distance to the endpoint in the worst-case analysis. 



If your facility has Program 2 or Program 3 processes, report one worst-case release scenario to represent all Program 2 and Program 3 processes having toxic regulated substances present above the threshold quantity, and one worst-case release scenario to represent all Program 2 and Program 3 processes having flammable regulated substances present above the threshold quantity. If you have more than one Program 2 or 3 process, you will report the worst-case release scenario for the Program 2 or 3 process that would have the greatest potential impact on the public (i.e., the greatest distance to endpoint). You may also need to submit an additional worst-case scenario for either hazard class (i.e., toxic or flammable), if a worst-case release from elsewhere at your facility would potentially affect a different set of public receptors than those affected by your initial worst-case scenario(s). 



2. Alternative release scenario analysis of Program 2 and Program 3 processes as follows: 

Present one alternative release scenario for each regulated toxic substance held above the threshold quantity in a Program 2 or 3 process, including the substance considered in the worst-case analysis. 

Present one alternative release scenario to represent all flammable substances held above the threshold quantity in a Program 2 or 3 process. 

Note that alternative release scenarios should be those that will reach an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.



The RRE1 fa

cility must report one (1) worst case release scenario for flammables and one (1) alternative release scenario for flammables under Program Level 2.

2.0    TOXIC WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

In accordance with EPA?s RMP guidance documents, at the time of the original filing, a toxic worst case scenario was not required to be evaluated. 



3.0    TOXIC ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

In accordance with EPA?s RMP guidance documents, at the time of the original filing, a toxic alternative release scenario was not required to be evaluated.



4.0    FLAMMABLE WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

A worst-case release scenario is defined by the EPA as ?the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or pipe that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a specifie

d endpoint, beyond which serious injury is not expected to occur?.  The worst-case release scenario is an analysis of how far away the worst possible accidental release from a facility would affect the surrounding public and environmental receptors.  This analysis is used to determine the facility?s program level under the RMP requirements.     

The EPA model RMP*Comp, version 1.07, was used to calculate the estimated distance to the worst-case flammable endpoint.  Model inputs include chemical type, quantity released, liquid temperature, and mitigation factors.  Isopentane is a flammable liquid and the model defines the worst-case release type as a vapor cloud explosion.  

The facility uses 183,000 pounds of isopentane within its storage and power generation processes and is the maximum quantity released during the worst-case scenario.  The estimated distance to the overpressure endpoint of one (1) pound per square inch (psi), determined by the RMP*Comp model, is 0.5 miles.  The results of the RMP*Comp modeling assessment are provided in Appendix B of this document.   

The radius of impact, as defined by the model, is 0.5 miles from the power generation facility.  The radius of impact is depicted in Figure A-3, provided in Appendix A of this document.  As shown in Figure A-3, one residential receptor is located within the radius of impact.  Since one residential receptor may be impacted during the worst-case scenario, the facility meets the requirements for a Program Level 2 facility.  



Table 4.1 below presents the data used to complete the worst-case and alternative release scenarios.  This information is intended to be compliant with 68 CFR 68.165(b).

Estim

Aid and Medical Treatment

First aid requirements from a release of isopentane at the Facility are likely to be in response to burns caused by fire or hot fluid.  All employees are trained on emergency response procedures for burns.  The burn response procedures are included in the Facility?s health and safety manual.



9.1.3    Response Procedures 

All employees are trained on responding to releases of isopentane.  The ORMAT control system will likely identify a release occurring at the facility.  If a release does occur the operator will be prompted by the control system alarm.  The operator will immediately initiate actions according the Facilities written isopentane Release Response procedures.  The procedures are maintained as part of the Facilities Emergency Response Manual.  Generally the procedures require notification of employees, shut-down of the system, an assessment of the situation, and response to the situation.  Facility evacuation and notification of emergency responders is required if the assessment of the situation indicates facility personnel are not capable of containing the release.



9.2    PROCEDURES FOR EMERGENCY RESPONSE EQUIPMENT

The Facility will prepare procedures for inspection, testing and maintenance of emergency response equipment.  These procedures are available in the Emergency Response Plan.



9.3    EMPLOYEE TRAINING

All employees will receive training with regards to procedures pertaining to an isopentane release.  According to the EPA General Guidance on Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention training records sufficient to demonstrate compliance with emergency plan training and equipment maintenance requirements are to be retained.  These documents are maintained as part of the Facility Emergency Response Plan.





9.4    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN REVIEW AND UPDATES

The Emergency Response Plan will be reviewed and updated if changes to the process occur.  Employees will be notified of the changes to the Emergency R

5.0    FLAMMABLE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

An alternative release scenario is considered more likely to occur than a worst-case scenario.  The alternative release scenario may include but is not limited to: hose splits or uncoupling; piping failure at flanges or valves, vessel overfilling or shipping container mishandling.  One alternative release scenario is required under Program Level 2.



The alternative scenario selected for this analysis was a boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE).  This type of explosion can occur when a vessel containing a pressurized flammable liquid is ruptured.  The total quantity of isopentane contained at the facility (183,000 pounds) was assumed to be involved in the BLEVE.  The estimated distance at which exposure may cause second-degree burns was estimated using the RMP*Comp model.  The estimated radius of exposure was determined to be 0.5 miles.  The alternative release scenario results using the RMP*Comp modeling assessment are provided in Appendix B of this document.   



The radius of exposure, as defined by the model, is 0.5 miles from the power generation process containing the isopentane.  The radius of impact is t

he same for both the worst case scenario and alternative release scenario.  The radius of impact is presented in Figure A-3, provided in Appendix A of this document.  As shown in Figure A-3, one residential receptor is located within the radius of exposure.

6.0    ACCIDENT HISTORY

According to 40 CFR 68.42(a), the owner or operator shall include reports of significant accidental releases of regulated substa

nces from covered processes in the five years prior to submittal of the RMP.  The following release criteria are required for the five-year accident history.

* The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance stored above its threshold quantity; and

* On- or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in-place.

At the time this RMP was prepared, the facility has not had a release meeting the above-listed criteria in the past five years.





7.0 PREVENTION PROGRAM 3

There are no Program 3 prevention processes subject to the RMP rule at the time of preparation and filing.



8.0 PREVENTION PROGRAM 2

The RMP prevention program is comprised of seven elements: (1) safety information; (2) hazard review; (3) operating procedures; (4) training; (5) maintenance; (6) compliance audits; and (7) incident investigation. This section of the RMP is intended to be compliant with 40 CFR 68.48 through 68.60.  Table 8.1 below presents the information required to comply with 40 CFR 170(a) through (c).  The Program 2 prevention processes are also summarized in the ?RMP*Submit 2004? form. The isopentane system utilizes 2 tanks to hold drain down solution. Sniffers are utilized to evaluate potential leaks. Deluge systems are installed around the storage tanks and critical handling equipment.





Table 8.1

8.1    SAFETY INFORMATION 

Safety information related to regulated substances and process equipment must be compiled and maintained.  This information includes the following elements.

8.1.1    Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs)

The facility must maintain MSDSs that meet the requirements of the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) under 29 CFR 1910.1200(g).  The MSDSs are retained as part of the facilities OSHA compliance program.

8.1.2    Maximum

Intended Inventory

The maximum intended inventory for isopentane at the Facility is 183,000 pounds.

8.1.3    Maximum and Minimum Process Parameters

The maximum and minimum process parameters for safe operation of the Program Level 2 equipment are presented in the Operations and Maintenance Manual.

8.1.4    Equipment Specifications

Equipment specifications are provided in the Operations and Maintenance Manual.

8.1.5    Building and Equipment Codes and Standards

The process equipment has been designed and tested according to NEC class I, division II, group D for operating conditions in hazardous areas.  Table 8.2 below provides information required to be compliant with 40 CFR 68.170(d).

8.2    HAZARD REVIEW

A hazard review is designed to detect process hazards and assess whether the facility is meeting applicable codes and standards; has identified, evaluated and addressed types of potential failures; and focused emergency response planning efforts.  The requirements of a hazard review include the review and identification of the following.



* Hazards associated with a Program Level 2 process and regulated substances;

* Opportunities for equipment malfunction or human error that could cause a release;

* Safeguards that control the hazard or prevent malfunction or error; and 

* Steps to detect or monitor a release.



Checklists may be used as a guide to conduct the review.  The results of the review shall be documented and identified problems resolved.  The review shall be conducted at least once ever five years, or when a major change in the process occurs

.  The facility hazard review is presented in Appendix C.  Table 7.2 below provides information required to be compliant with 40 CFR 68.170(e).

8.3    OPERATING PROCEDURES 

Operating procedures detail the tasks a process operator must perform, set safe process operating parameters that must be maintained, and determine safety precautions for operators and maintenance activities.  Requirements for an operating procedures document include assigning a step to each operational phase, including:



* Initial startup;

* Normal operations;

* Temporary operations;

* Emergency shutdown and operations;

* Normal shutdown; 

* Startup following a normal or emergency shutdown, or major change;

* Consequences of deviations and steps required to correct or avoid deviations; and

* Equipment inspections.



The date of the latest review or revision to the ORMAT operating procedures is May 1, 2007. However, the operating procedures may be updated, as necessary, without revision to this RMP.  Operating procedures for the Raft River Facility are available in the ORMAT Operations and Maintenance Manual Section 5.  



8.4    TRAINING 

Workers must be trained and competent in the process operating procedures.  In addition to the process-specific training, the facility is required by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) to provide training under the Hazard Communication Standard (29 CFR 1910.1200) with regards to chemical hazards and exposure prevention.  Additionally, the Department of Transportation requires training for loading and unloading hazardous chemicals (49 CFR part 172, subpart H).  Refresher training will be provided at least every three years.

Preparation and implementation of procedures to maintain process equipment, and train workers on maintenance procedures is required. 8.6    COMPLIANCE AUDITS

A compliance audit should be conducted to ensure the RMP has been properly implemented.  A compliance audit must be completed by at least one person knowledgeable in the process at least every three years to certify compliance with prevention program requirements for each Program Level 2 process.  



Compliance audit documentation includes audit findings, the response to the findings, and correction of noted deficiencies.  The two most recent audits conducted within a five year period must be retained.  Table 8.6 below provides information required to be compliant with 40 CFR 68.170(i).

8.7    INCIDENT INVESTIGATION 

Under the RMP, facility operators are required to investigate incidents which ?result in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance?.  It is recommended that minor accidents or near misses also be investigated to identify problems that could lead to more serious accidents.  The incident investigation requirements include:



* Initiation of an investigation within 48 hours of the incident;

* Prepare a report summarizing the incident including: (1) date of incident; (2) date investigation began; (3) description of incident; (4) factors contributing to incident; and (5) recommendations resulting from the investigation;

* Addressing and resolving the report findings and recommendations.  Resolutions and corrective actions shall be documented;

* Review report findings and recommendations with workers with job tasks relevant to incident; and

* Retain incident investigation report for five years.



Table 8.7 below provides information required to be compliant with 40 CFR 68.170(j) and (k).  Copies of incident investigations (if any) are included in Appendix F.

9.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE 

Development of a management system includes assigning a qualified person or position with the responsibility to oversee the development, implementation and integration of the RMP.  This portion of the RMP is intended to comply with 40 CFR 68.15.

The EPA General Guidance on Risk

Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention Section 5.2 suggests that small facilities, with few employees, need only identify the one person or position with the overall responsibility of implementing the elements of the RMP.  The overall responsibility for the RMP resides with the Plant Manager.  At the time of this RMP development, the Plant Manager was Mr. Chris Harriman.  The Plant Manager may change without need for resubmitting the RMP.  Emergency response contacts and their telephone numbers are included in Table 1.1 Facility Registration Information in Section 1.0 of this document.

The CFR Part 68 requires that a Program Level 2 facility implement an emergency response program if site employees respond to a release involving a regulated substance.  The emergency response program consists of the following:



* An Emergency Response Plan:

* Procedures for inspection, testing and maintenance of emergency response equipment;

* Employee training; and

* Review and update of the emergency response plan with regard to changes at the facility.



The emergency response program elements are discussed further in the following sections and Table 9.1.



9.1    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

The facility employees will respond to occurrences which may result, or are likely to result in an uncontrolled release of isopentane.  Facility response is necessary due to the potential for volatilization of a spill or spread of fire.  This section is intended to comply with 40 CFR Section 68.95.



9.1.1 Procedures for Notifications

If a release of isopentane exceeds the response capabilities of the Facility, the following notification procedures will be followed:



1. Call 911 to contact emergency responders;



2. Evacuate facility personnel to a staging area outside of the impact zone identified in the worst case release analysis; and



3. Contact and evacuate the residence located north of the Facility that is within the worst case release impact area.
